abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Road Upgrading Project, is
            rated marginally satisfactory, for, although all physical
            components were achieved, high cost increases, due to slow
            economic growth, limited an otherwise, satisfactory
            operation. The lessons show that better preliminary
            engineering, and detailed geo-technical studies, along with
            the right use of regional comparators, would achieve more
            advanced economic, and cost evaluation tools to assess,
            realistically, the viability of an operation. It is further
            suggested that environmental management should be
            strengthened in future operations with the Public Works
            Department (PWD), particularly addressing the environmental,
            geo-technical, and slope failure mitigation measures, at the
            design stage of sup-projects, and, since the private sector
            participation in local works, and services proved effective,
            PWD should be encouraged to expand outsourcing, because its
            inadequate capacity for implementing civil works, and
            services, hindered project implementation. Although the
            parallel co-financing relationship with the Asian
            Development Bank in the administrative capacity, succeeded
            during project preparation, and implementation, procedural
            differences, such as the absence of certain controls in
            procurement, or the slow pace in land acquisition, suggest
            the preference for uniform procedures, as a pre-condition to
            co-financing, thus, subsequent co-financing could remain dubious.

display_title.display_title:
Fiji - Second Road Upgrading
            Project : Implementation Completion Report

5079265.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Urban development

abstracts.cdata!:
The principal aim of the project is to
            assist the Government in promoting balanced economic
            development through improvements in the efficiency of the
            land transport system.  In order to enable the road
            transport sector to better meet the needs of growing traffic
            between agricultural areas, commercial centers and ports as
            well as from tourism developments, in a cost-effective
            manner, the project aims at: (1) upgrading and improving the
            road network; (2) improving road traffic safety and traffic
            management; (3) strengthening the capacity of road
            authorities to manage the road network; and (4) improving
            sector policies in the key areas of maintenance practices
            and funding, control of road damage by heavy vehicles, road
            user taxation, and increased construction efficiency through
            the introduction of contracting of roadworks to the private
            sector on a competitive basis.
